A car accident left Grayson Russell with broken bones, a brain injury and Post Concussive Syndrome. His diagnoses included issues like light sensitivity, anxiety, cognitive delays and loss of physical coordination.

In the face of these physical challenges, Grayson was also at risk of losing an entire semester of credit at his traditional high school. His family decided to pursue EPIC’s virtual education format instead. Nearly three years later, Grayson and his family call it ‘the perfect choice’.

Read more about Grayson and his journey at: https://epiccharterschools.org/student-spotlight-grayson-russell.html

#EPICDareGreatly #SchoolCanBeDifferent

During a time of transition, the Arnold family decided to give EPIC a try. For their soon-to-be seventh grader, the switch from brick-and-mortar was a success.

The virtual setting has benefited Rex’s academic performance, as well as the pursuit of his passions: golf and flying.

“EPIC allows Rex to decide when to practice and play. He looks at the forecast each week to decide the best days to practice,” Rex’s mother, Kimberly Arnold, said. “This teaches him to make decisions and self-manage his time.”

Along with the flexibility, the Arnold family appreciates a strong partnership with their son’s teacher.

“Being responsible for your child’s education can be overwhelming at first,” Kimberly said. “His teacher is not only an academic resource, but she also helps navigate National Collegiate Athletic Association rules and regulations in case my children decide to pursue college athletics.

“As a result of our teacher-parent partnership, Rex has straight A’s and is doing well on testing. EPIC has really changed our life as a family,” said Kimberly.

“Being at EPIC has made Jasmine a stronger student and teen,” her mother said. “Not only are the teachers awesome, but you make your own schedule.”

We have been getting a lot of questions today because of news reports like this. Please know that regardless of what other school districts may have or choose to do this summer, EPIC will not begin its 2020-2021 school year early. We will begin as we do every year, the Tuesday after Labor Day, which is September 8. Our school year will end as it always does, too, which is the last Friday in May, 2021. Of course, as is always the case, individual students can work ahead and, as such, complete their school year earlier. That is the beauty of individualized learning. We are prepared to continue to provide the highest quality distance learning to any Oklahoma family who needs us.

EPIC is proud to contribute to this balance between life and learning. Because of the way EPIC’s alternative learning options have benefited their family, the Fowlkes offer this final word of advice:

“Any parent considering alternative schooling should seriously consider EPIC!”

Seventh-grader, Annika Sinning’s ice-skating career is much more extensive than most would guess. She has been skating for nearly a decade, being first introduced to the ice at the age of two.

With countless titles and hours of training under her belt, the EPIC student has a clear goal in mind.

“I want to get to the Olympics,” Annika said.

Because of EPIC’s flexible schedule, combined with Annika’s outstanding skill and work-ethic, this is not an unrealistic goal to set.

“Training up to six hours a day required more flexibility than a brick and mortar school was able to provide,” her mother said. “This week, for example, Annika is training in Chicago without missing school. EPIC makes that possible.”

While EPIC equips Annika to continue the pursuit of her dream, her family reminds others to leverage this same freedom.

“EPIC works for Annika and it can work for your child, too.”
#EPICDareGreatly #SchoolCanBeDifferent
